title: Carlos Gabriel Salazar
text:
Carlos Gabriel Salazar (born September 5, 1964 in Presidencia Roque Sáenz Peña) is a retired <a href="Boxing">boxer</a> from <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>, who competed in the light flyweight division (– 71 kg). He was scheduled to represent his native country at the <a href="Boxing%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles, California</a>, but he lost his first-round bout via walkover to <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a>'s <a href="Rafael%20Ramos%20%28boxer%29">Rafael Ramos</a>.
1984 Olympic results.
Below is the record of Carlos Gabriel Salazar, a light flyweight boxer from Argentina who was entered in the 1984 Olympic boxing tournament in Los Angeles:
Professional career.
As a professional he had 58 fights (47-3-8), from 1985 to 1998. He campaigned at the flyweight and super flyweight divisions, winning world titles in both. After 3 unsuccessful attempts at the world title, Salazar became the <a href="International%20Boxing%20Federation">IBF</a> World super flyweight champion when he beat <a href="Harold%20Grey">Harold Grey</a> in 1995. He would defend the title once before losing it to the same Harold Grey. After that he decided to move down to flyweight and campaign for the <a href="World%20Boxing%20Organization">WBO</a> World title, winning it against <a href="Alberto%20Jim%C3%A9nez%20%28boxer%29">Alberto Jiménez</a>. He defended that title 5 times before losing it to <a href="Rub%C3%A9n%20S%C3%A1nchez%20Le%C3%B3n">Rubén Sánchez León</a> in controversial fashion as he cited he was hit after the referee had stopped actions and the punch caused him a broken jaw. Salazar decided to retire from boxing after the fight citing medical issues.
